newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovakia, Japan EXIM bank near agreement on loan.
newsitem.headline: Slovakia, Japan EXIM bank near agreement on loan.

text.p: The National Bank of Slovakia (NBS) and the Export-Import Bank of Japan are close to signing a loan of around 20 billion yen ($161.7 million) to support small and medium-sized Slovak companies, the daily Narodna Obroda reported on Thursday.

"We are in the final stage of negotiations over the third loan from (Japan's) Exim bank and are talking about 20 billion yen," the paper quoted NBS governor Vladimir Masar as saying during his visit to Japan.

Masar added the maturity of the credit should be "around 12 years". He declined to disclose information about the loan's rate, but said it should be "relatively favourable". NBS officials were not immediately available for comment.
Masar and a government delegation headed by Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar, are scheduled to return to Slovakia on Thursday night.

The NBS signed a 10 billion yen credit facility with the Japanese Exim Bank in April 1996. It held an interest rate equivalent to the Slovak discount rate -- currently 8.8 percent -- plus 3.25 percent and was also used to support small and medium-sized entreprises.

The funds were redistributed through a group of domestic commercial banks. It is still unclear whether this will also be the case for the latest credit or whether the NBS will chose a single commercial bank as agent to distribute the funds.
